subject: Entrepreneurship
title: TOMS Shoes: The Rise and Rethink
description: A fast breakdown of TOMS Shoes: The Rise and Rethink for builders.

hook.text: In 2006, Blake Mycoskie saw children in Argentina walking barefoot. He came home and started TOMS Shoes.

buildup.text: His promise was radical: buy a pair of shoes, and TOMS gives a pair to a child in need. Sales exploded.

discovery.text: TOMS gave away over 100 million pairs of shoes. The brand became synonymous with conscious capitalism.

twist.text: Then studies showed free shoes hurt local shoemakers in developing countries, destroying their businesses.

climax.text: TOMS abandoned one-for-one and switched to donating a third of profits. The original model had to evolve.

punchline.text: Good intentions needed better economics to truly help.

quiz.question: Why did TOMS eventually move away from its one-for-one shoe donation model?
options: They ran out of shoes to donate and couldn't keep up with demand
Studies showed free shoes damaged local shoemaking businesses in recipient countries
Customers stopped buying because they preferred traditional shoe brands
